newsitem.title: UK: NWE fuel oil markets steady to slightly higher.
newsitem.headline: NWE fuel oil markets steady to slightly higher.

text.p: European fuel markets were steady to slightly higher on Thursday as barges were boosted by bunker demand while low sulphur was steady with traders saying it was a little better supplied.
High sulphur fuel barges traded at a high of $82 and $83 a tonne fob in the ARA area after earlier trades at $79 and $80 a tonne, slightly better than Wednesday.
One trader said bunker demand was "not bad" at about 25,000 tonnes by mid-day. Another said that high sulphur was talked in the $81/$82 region later in the day.

Traders said an Italian trader and a Portugese refiner won bids on Wednesday to each supply 25,000 tonnes of high sulphur fuel oil to state-run Electricidade de Portugal, which took up an option for a third similar cargo to be supplied by the local refiner. No low sulphur fuel oil cargoes were heard moved. Traders said the market was a little better supplied, with offers and bids steady in the $96 and $94 fob area. "It was a very dead market, nothing happening," one seller said, adding he would not show new cargoes before the end of June.

One trader said lesser Russian material was on offer with some berths at the country's main Black Sea oil port of Novorossiisk shut due an oil spill last week. "Novorossiisk is shut because of the pollution incident so there is delay down there. There are some pieces on the water but I think they will go fairly easy, especially if there are delays to the programme now out of Novo," one trader said.

"I think there will be delays because it is a sizeable spillage they had there. Three berths are closed at Novorossiisk after some 400 tonnes of oil spilled at a terminal when a pipeline burst open on Tuesday night. -Haitham Haddadin, London newsroom +44 171 542 8145
